Authors:
Eduardo Pérez-Pazos, Margarita Villegas-Ríos, Roberto
Garibay-Orijel, Rodolfo Salas-Lizana
Title:
Two new species of Clavulina and the first record of
Clavulina reae from temperate Abies religiosa forests in central
Mexico
Keywords:
Cantharellales, Clavulinaceae, coral fungi, species
complex, taxonomy
Abstract:
Clavulina is a genus of macroscopic fungi, mostly with
clavarioid basidiomata, distributed worldwide. The most commonly
reported species are C. amethystina, C. coralloides, C. cinerea, and C.
rugosa, which form a species complex in temperate ecosystems. In this
work, we describe two new species for the genus: C. parvispora and C.
mahiscolorata; these species show great resemblance with previously
described species. Nevertheless they represent new lineages distributed
in temperate forests from central Mexico. We also present the first
record of C. reae from Mexico, which displays great macro-morphological
variation regarding basidiomata branching rank, colors, and tips shape.
We also provide macromorphological, micromorphological, and habitat data
are given for each species, as well as nrDNA ITS sequences recovered
from basidiomata and ectomycorrhizae. Our findings highlight an
underestimation of the potential richness for the genus in temperate
ecosystems, as a consequence of misallocation of common epithets to
undescribed similar taxa. The designation of neotypes for temperate
species of Clavulina is urgent, in order to delimitate species concepts
for each species described for the genus, which seems to be very diverse
in temperate ecosystems.
